rsbNotes.title: Ps 26:1
rsbNotes.text: 26:1 in my integrity. David identifies himself in motive and action with the righteous rather than the wicked. He invites God to test the truth of this claim (v. 2). David has no illusions of being sinless (53:5) or of having no need for mercy (v. 11; 130:3).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 26:4
rsbNotes.text: 26:4 I do not sit. Cf. Ps. 1:1.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 26:6
rsbNotes.text: 26:6 your altar. The language fits a prayer for admission to the sanctuary.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 26:9
rsbNotes.text: 26:9 sinners. He wants to distance himself from the wicked, for if they enter the sanctuary precincts (vv. 6â€“8), they will be quickly destroyed. David asks to be spared this judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 26:12
rsbNotes.text: 26:12 on level ground. A metaphor for personal stability and right relationship with the Lord.
